questions.text:
Your friend is planning on setting up a granite factory consisting of 25 female and 275 male employees. He asks for your advice on health, safety, and welfare. Which of the following will be required?
  1. Creches
  2. Safety Officer
  3. Welfare officer
  4. Canteen
questions.solution:
Based on the number of employees, a canteen and a crèche will be required.

According to The Factories act, 1948, for a total number of 300 employees, a canteen is an adequate welfare measure. And according to the Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, a creche will also be required when there are 50 or more employees (inclusive of males and females).

The employment of a safety officer is unwarranted when the number of employees does not exceed 1000. The employment of a welfare officer is required when the number of workers exceed 500.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following in the matters of Safety and Welfare measures:

  • > 1000 Workers in a factory – the appointment of 'Safety Officers'
  • > 500 Workers – there should be a Welfare Officer
  • > 250 Workers – a canteen shall be provided
  • > 30 female workers- Crèche

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of males and females). As this act is more recent, it supersedes the Factory Act, 1948 with regards to the requirement for a crèche.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy developed on and off fever which was not medically treated. After a week he presented with jaundice, malaise, neck stiffness, and photophobia. They give a history of rescuing a stray dog about two weeks back. On work-up, he was found to have deranged hepatic parameters as given below. A spinal tap was performed and the CSF showed the following organism on microscopy. Which serogroup of the causative organism is most likely commonly responsible for causing this condition?

ALT - 203 U/L

AST - 82 U/L

ALP - 198 U/L
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing influenza-like symptoms, jaundice, and features of aseptic meningitis and history of rescuing a stray dog, along with an electron microscopy image of a spirochete is suggestive of leptospirosis. The most common serovar causing aseptic meningitis is canicola.

Leptospirosis is caused by contact with the blood or urine of an infected organism in a contaminated water body. It is a type of zoonosis and can affect all mammalian species, rats are well-known reservoirs. 

The clinical picture varies from mild disease to fatal disease (Weil's disease). Signs and symptoms of leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, meningismus, hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury (hematuria and elevated BUN). Anemia in leptospirosis is due to blood loss.

A microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosis of Leptospirosis after 1 week.

In the acute phase of the disease, leptospires can be seen in blood in the first week of infection.

Leptospires are sensitive to penicillin and tetracyclines and the treatment should be started early in the course of the disease.

Serious cases of leptospirosis are most often caused by serotype icterohemorrhagiae (Weil's disease) where rats are the common animal reservoir. They may also be due to copenhageni and less often due to bataviae, grippotyphosa (field mice are the common animal reservoir) and pyrogenes (pigs are the common animal reservoir). 

Aseptic meningitis is common in canicola infection and abdominal symptoms in grippotyphosa infections.

L.pomona causes Swineherd's disease where pigs are the major animal reservoir.

questions.text: A young woman presented with mood disturbance, tearfulness, and a lack of energy on the 5th day of postpartum. She was counseled and educated about postpartum blues. She should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last longer than:
questions.solution:
The patient should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last >2 weeks.

Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood and sadness. It typically develops within one week of delivery. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. Treatment is nothing more than education and support, however, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is characterized by a minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation lasting for >2 weeks. It is usually seen within the 4-6 weeks. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby. 

Postpartum psychosis or puerperal psychosis is a psychotic disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. It is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset of 2-3 weeks postpartum although it can occur in the first few days. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by insomnia, restlessness, agitation, lability of mood, and mild cognitive deficits. The treatment of choice involves antipsychotics and lithium, with an antidepressant. 

Postpartum delirium is characterized by fluctuating levels of awareness or attention. 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical tests is not useful to evaluate a patient with suspected rotator cuff disruption?
questions.solution:
The Roo's test is used to reproduce the symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Usually, following a trauma to the rotator cuff, there is a vascular reaction that causes swelling and subsequent rotator cuff impingement.

Rotator cuff disruption is an advanced stage of impingement. There is progressive fibrosis and disruption of the rotator cuff, leading to a partial or full-thickness tear. The patient is usually more than 45 years of age and has a history of refractory shoulder pain with weakness and stiffness.

The muscles forming the rotator cuff are shown below.

Important tests for cuff impingement are:

  • Painful arc test- on active abduction of the arm between 60 and 120 degrees, pain is aggravated.
  • Neer’s impingement sign- the examiner stabilizes the scapula with one hand, and with the other hand, the affected arm is raised fully in passive flexion, abduction, and internal rotation. The test is positive when pain in the subacromial space or anterior part acromion on performing this maneuver. 
  • Neer’s test for impingement- disappearance or significant reduction in pain when the previous maneuver is repeated after injecting 10 mL of 1% lignocaine into the subacromial space. It helps in the confirmation of the diagnosis.
  • Hawkins–Kennedy test- the patient’s arm is elevated 90 degrees in the scapular plane with the elbow in 90 degrees flexion. The upper arm is then stabilized and rotated internally. The test is positive when pain is felt in the anterolateral part of the shoulder. This test is also highly sensitive but weakly specific.
  • Jobe’s test- the patient's arm is elevated in the scapular plane, and the elbow is extended with the thumb pointing to the floor. The patient is then asked to hold this position, while the examiner applies downward pressure. Pain indicates irritation of the supraspinatus tendon.

 The images below summarize the various tests for cuff impingement.

Roo's test- the patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is then asked to open and close the hand slowly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, or numbness, on the affected side. It is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome.

The GIF below demonstrates Roo's test.

Related Pearl: Important tests and signs to assess the function of rotator cuff muscles

Tests Muscles tested

Empty can test

  Supraspinatus
Resisted external rotation  Infraspinatus

Lift-off test

Belly press test

  Subscapularis

Abduction paradox

Drop arm sign

  Seen in the complete   rupture of rotator cuff
 Lag sign  Seen in tear of   supraspinatus or   infraspinatus
 Drop sign  Seen in the tear in the   infraspinatus and the   posterior part of the   rotator cuff

questions.text: A baby having a continuous murmur was sent for cardiac evaluation.  2-D echocardiography showed a connection from the aorta to the main pulmonary artery and color doppler imaging revealed left to right shunting from the aorta into the main pulmonary artery. Which among the following syndromes is not likely to be associated with this cardiac condition?
questions.solution:
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), the most likely diagnosis in this scenario is not usually associated with Marfan's Syndrome. Marfan's syndrome is associated with aortic aneurysms and mitral valve disease.

Conditions commonly associated with a patent ductus arteriosus are:

  • Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, valve abnormalities)
  • Patau's syndrome (Trisomy 13- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, valve abnormalities)
  • Cri du chat (deletion of chromosome 5p15.2- Atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, Tetrology of Fallot)
  • Noonan's syndrome (Pulmonic stenosis, atrial septal defect, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)
  • Char syndrome (craniofacial, limb defects, PDA)
  • Congenital Rubella syndrome

PDA is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. The ductus arteriosus attaches to the aorta just distal to the left subclavian artery. It closes functionally and anatomically soon after birth. Its persistence causes left to right shunt and is known is called PDA. 

On examination, there are prominent carotid pulsations, hyperkinetic cardiac impulse, palpable systolic or a continuous thrill at the second left intercostal space with continuous machinery murmur.

On chest x-ray, patients with a large PDA show a prominent pulmonary artery with increased pulmonary vascular markings. On an echocardiogram, the ductus can be visualized directly and its size can be estimated. Color and pulsed Doppler examinations demonstrate rleft to right or bidrectional shunting. 

Treatment is by medical closure with indomethacin or by surgical closure of the ductus. 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication

Ebstein anomaly

Eisenmenger's syndrome

VSD with pulmonic stenosis

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to you with dull persistent ear pain. On examination, a palpable mass with a bulge is noted in the tonsillar fossa. X-ray reveals the following finding marked with the red arrow as shown in the image attached below. Pick out the incorrect statement regarding the condition, the patient is most likely to be suffering from?

choices.text: Pain occurs due to direct irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve
Classically seen in female patients following tonsillectomy
External transcervical approach is the most preferred technique
Diagnosis can be made if pain subsides on local infiltration with local anesthetics

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette in a woman with referred pain to the ear and bulge over the tonsillar fossa, along with the X-ray showing elongated and calcified styloid process is suggestive of Eagle's syndrome (styalgia).  The transoral approach through the tonsillar fossa is generally favoured over the external transcervical approach because of the lower morbidity.

Other options:

  • The normal styloid process is 20-30 mm long in adults and is generally accepted to be elongated if exceeding 30 mm. Pain occurs due to direct irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve by the elongated styloid process and ossified stylohyoid ligament. (Option-A)
  • Usually, this condition is seen post-tonsillectomy or post pharyngeal trauma. It is more common in females (3:1). (Option-B)
  • Palpation should elicit the same pain and discomfort that the patient reports and are pathognomonic of Eagle’s syndrome. In contrast, infiltration of a local anaesthetic around the tonsillar fossa should resolve the pain and can be useful diagnostically (Option-D)
 

Related Pearl: Eagle syndrome

Also called the kerato-stylohyoidal syndrome is characterized by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament.

Etiology: Usually, this condition is seen post-tonsillectomy or post pharyngeal trauma. It is more common in Females (3:1).

Clinical Presentation:

  • Commonly bilateral
  • Presentation 1: Classic Eagle syndrome
    • Dull and persistent pharyngeal pain often referred to the ear.
    • Pain exacerbated by rotation of the head.
    • A palpable mass or a bulge in the tonsillar fossa.
    • Other associated symptoms like dysphagia, foreign body sensation, tinnitus and cervicofacial pain may be seen.
  • Presentation 2: Stylocarotid syndrome
    • Compression of the internal or external carotid artery by medially or laterally rotated styloid process.

Treatment: Styloidectomy in those not responding to conservative treatment with analgesics.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman from a rural area presents with a gritty sensation in her eyes and a past history of salivary gland swelling. She is on oral pilocarpine and steroids. Rose Bengal staining is positive as shown below, especially in the interpalpebral areas. Schirmer's test shows 7mm of wetting in 5 minutes. Which of the following layers of tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the the findings of interpalpebral conjunctival involvement on rose bengal stain and dry eye on Schirmer's test (< 10 mm in 5 minutes) indicate keratoconjunctivitis sicca. It occurs due to a deficiency of the aqueous layer of tear film.

She also has a history of parotid swelling and dry eyes, both of which are characteristic of Sjogren’s syndrome, which is a common cause of keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Her use of oral pilocarpine to stimulate salivary gland secretion and steroids for immunosuppression further supports the diagnosis.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

Causes:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies- congenital, infiltration by tumours or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction- old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes)- Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Clinical features:

Patients often experience a sandy or gritty sensation under the eyelids, stringy discharge, transient blurring of vision, and redness with crusting of the eyelids. A burning sensation, lack of emotional or reflex tearing, and symptom exacerbation with exposure to air-conditioning, heat, prolonged reading, or screen time are also common.

On examination, there may be signs of posterior seborrheic blepharitis, positive Rose Bengal staining, keratinization, conjunctivochalasis, corneal plaques, and tear film abnormalities.

Evaluation includes tests like tear film break-up time, Schirmer's test, Rose Bengal staining, fluorescein clearance timing, tear film osmolarity, phenol red thread test, tear meniscometry, and impression cytology.

Diagnostic evaluation of keratoconjunctivitis sicca includes measurement of tear flow by Schirmer I test and determination of tear composition, with an assessment of tear breakup time or tear lysozyme content. Slit-lamp examination of the cornea and conjunctiva after rose bengal staining reveals punctuate corneal ulcerations and attached filaments of corneal epithelium.

Treatment:

  • Education and lifestyle modification
  • Medical management: Tear substitutes, mucolytic agents, topical steroids, topical cyclosporin, antibiotics, secretagogues like cevimeline
  • Surgical management: Punctal occlusion, eyelid tarsorrhaphy, amniotic membrane transplantation
  • Others: Contact lenses, Antibiotics, moister chamber spectacles and shields.

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the dermatology clinic with the condition shown in the image below. The discoloration started as a streak in the nail which progressed proximally to involve the entire nail. Which among the following drugs is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment of a mild version of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem is suggestive of onychomycosis for which amorolfine, is available as a nail lacquer for the treatment. Oxiconazole, griseofulvin, and tioconazole are not available as nail lacquers.

Onychomycosis or tinea unguium refers to the invasion of the nail plate by dermatophytes, or other fungi like Neoscytalidium, non‐ dermatophyte molds, and Candida. 

Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) is the most common and usually presents as a streak or a patch of yellow or white discoloration at the free edge of the nail plate. It then spreads towards the base of the nail and may become dark brown or black. There is an accumulation of soft subungual hyperkeratosis, thickening of the nail plate, and the nail may eventually crack.

Further invasion can lead to massive destruction of the nail plate,  known as total dystrophic onychomycosis. It can spread to other digits as well.

Treatment:

First-line drugs- Oral terbinafine for 6 weeks for fingernails and for 3 months for toenails. Itraconazole is given for 2-3 months for fingernails and 3-4 months for toenails.

Topical treatment can be used for mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis. Amorolfine is available for nail lacquer that can be painted on the nail. It is applied after abrading the nail once or twice weekly. It is more effective when used with terbinafine or itraconazole as a combination therapy for onychomycosis.

Other options:

Option B: Oxiconazole is administered as a 1% cream or lotion for topical use.

Option C: Griseofulvin is administered orally.

Option D: Tioconazole is administered as a nail solution, ointment, or cream but not as a nail lacquer.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: An infant was brought to the emergency with an incessant cry, abdominal distension, and passing blood-stained stools.  A donut-shaped mass was visualized in the right hypochondrium on ultrasonography. On performing barium studies, which sign would be consistent with the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of an infant with incessant crying, abdominal distension, and blood-stained stools with a doughnut sign on ultrasonography is suggestive of intussusception. On performing barium studies, coiled spring appearance is consistent with the diagnosis of this condition. 

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. 

Causes of intussusception are:

  • Idiopathic - most common cause in children
  • Pathological lead points such as enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
  • Meckel's diverticulum
  • A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children.

The characteristic clinical triad includes:

  • Pain
  • Palpable sausage-shaped mass
  • Red currant jelly stools

USG findings in intussusception include:

  • Target sign/ doughnut sign/ bull's eye sign - This is seen in axial view/transverse plane on ultrasonography. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic (mucosa and muscularis) with hypoechogenic bands (submucosa).
  • Pseudo kidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:
    • Edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma 
    • Mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Barium contrast shows a coiled spring appearance with barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space. Plain radiograph may show a meniscus sign i.e. soft tissue mass contrasting the bowel that is air-filled. 

Treatment: Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis. Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a high success rate in ileocolic intussusception. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences.

Other options:

Options A and D: Pseudo kidney sign and target sign are ultrasonographic findings of instussuception. 

The ultrasonography image below shows pseudo kidney sign and target sign:

 

Option B: The corkscrew pattern is pathognomic of midgut volvulus on upper GI studies. It represents the duodenum and jejunum spiralling around the mesenteric vessels.

questions.text:
You are a pathologist and you receive a renal biopsy sample for which immunofluorescence has to be done. On observation, you notice the following pattern. Which of the following diseases are ruled out according to the pattern observed?
  1. Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
  2. Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN) Type I
  3. Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis Type II
  4. Membranous Nephropathy
  5. Minimal Change disease
  6. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) Type I
  7. Goodpasture Syndrome
questions.solution:
The given pattern of immunofluorescence microscopy is the "granular pattern" which is not seen in 2, 5, and 7.

Granular pattern in immunofluorescence microscopy is characteristic of circulating and in situ immune complex nephritis.

In RPGN Type I and Goodpasture syndrome, a characteristic linear pattern is observed on immunofluorescence which is classic anti-GBM disease.

In minimal change disease, immunofluorescence is negative.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

 Focal mesangial proliferative glomerulo-nephritis; mesangial widening  IgA ± IgG, IgM, and C3 in mesangium Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits 

Alport syndrome

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte 

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

 Negative 

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3, C1q, C4 deposits 

IgG deposits

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative  pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3 deposits;

No C1q and C4 deposits

No IgG deposits

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

 IgG4 and C3  Fibrillar deposits in the mesangium and capillary walls

 

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text:
Match the gastrointestinal hormones in column A to the cells producing them in column B.
Column A Column B
1. Cholecystokinin a. G cells
2. Gastric inhibitory peptide b. M cells
3.Gastrin c. C cells
4. Motilin d. I cells
  e. K cells
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-d, 2-e, 3-a, 4-b.

Gastrointestinal hormones- site of secretion and their actions

Hormones Site of secretion Action

Gastrin

G cells of the antrum, duodenum, and jejunum

Stimulates gastric acid secretion and mucosal growth

Cholecystokinin

I cells of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum

Stimulates

  • Pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Growth of exocrine pancreas

Inhibits gastric emptying

Secretin

S cells of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum

Stimulates

  • Pepsin secretion
  • Pancreatic bicarbonate secretion
  • Biliary bicarbonate secretion
  • Growth of exocrine pancreas

Inhibits gastrin release and gastric acid secretion

Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (also called gastric inhibitory peptide- GIP)

K cells of the duodenum and jejunum

Stimulates insulin release

Inhibits gastric acid secretion

Motilin

M cells of the duodenum and jejunum

Stimulates

  • Gastric motility
  • Intestinal motility
Somatostatin D cells of pancreas

Inhibits the secretion of various gastrointestinal hormones, gastrointestinal motility, and absorption of glucose, amino acids, and triglycerides.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is diagnosed to have aortic dissection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Involvement of only the descending aorta requires emergency surgical repair
Can be associated with Marfan syndrome

questions.solution:
The management of aortic dissection that involves only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) is antihypertensive drugs, not emergency surgery.

Aortic dissection occurs due to the formation of a defect in the intima of the aorta, leading to the tracking of the blood through the layers of the aorta, splitting the medial layer, and thus forming a false lumen. The predisposing factors to aortic dissection include:

  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome and other disorders of connective tissue that can cause degeneration of the tunica media of the aorta, like Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and giant cell arteritis.
  • Pregnancy

The patients present with a sudden onset, tearing interscapular pain with dyspnea. General physical examination may show hypotension or hypertension and loss of pulses. Extension of the dissection in either direction can lead to symptoms related to the organ with compromised perfusion, as given below:

  • Proximal extension can involve head and neck vessels (causing stroke or transient ischemic attack), coronary vessels (causing myocardial infarction) and the root of the aorta (causing aortic regurgitation).
  • Distal extension can involve renal arteries (acute kidney injury), mesenteric arteries (mesenteric ischemia), spinal arteries (paraplegia) and iliac arteries (acute limb ischemia).
  • The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are too unstable for transportation. In otherwise stable patients, the diagnosis is established by a CT scan. Depending on the part of the aorta involved, aortic dissections are classified as shown in the image below. 

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection (irrespective of the type) is to control hypertension and pain. A β-blocker is used parenterally, such as intravenous esmolol, to control the BP and reduce the heart rate. Sodium nitroprusside can be further added to reduce the systolic pressure to <120 mmHg.

Further management depends on the type of aortic dissection. In Stanford type A dissections, surgical intervention is required. In type B dissections, antihypertensive management is usually enough. Further intervention is indicated in type B dissections if:

  • There is an increase in the pain — which could be a sign of impending rupture
  • Dissection is associated with signs of reduced perfusion of organ or limb

In these complicated type B dissections, percutaneous endovascular stenting is done. Surgery is reserved for patients in whom this procedure fails.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Identify the structure marked X in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland.

The C-cells are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

Option D: Hürthle cells are oncocytes with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and a vesicular nucleus with a large nucleolus found in the thyroid arising from follicular cells. They are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis, Hürthle cell adenoma and Hürthle cell carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A man complains of fatigue and numbness in his hands and feet. On examination, he looked pale and his reflexes were poor. The peripheral smear showed a megaloblastic picture. Which of the following tests can differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency?

choices.text: Methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine
Hypersegmented neutrophils in peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
Measurement of methylmalonic acid (MMA) excretion in urine can be used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. 

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12–dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to the accumulation of methylmalonic acid in serum and its excretion in urine.

The test for MMA excretion is also used to assess the nutritional status of vitamin B12.

There are two vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. This requires both vitamin B12 and folate.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl-CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA, is converted to succinyl CoA.

Homocysteine will be elevated in both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. 

The figure below shows vitamin B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Diagnosis

Basophilic stippling, target cells

Elliptocytes, target cells

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Chronic liver disease

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart?
questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart.

Late sodium current (INa) facilitates entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension, cardiac contractility and work.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation, which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilization.

It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 75-kg woman has a preoperative hematocrit of 35%. How much blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered? (Consider transfusion cut off of Hematocrit as 30%)
questions.solution:
750 ml blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered

The transfusion point can be determined preoperatively from the hematocrit and by estimating blood volume. Patients with a normal hematocrit should generally be transfused only after losses greater than 10–20% of their blood volume. The exact point is based on the patient’s medical condition and the surgical procedure. The amount of blood loss necessary for the hematocrit to fall to 30% can be calculated as follows:

  1. Estimate blood volume
  2. Estimate the red blood cell volume (RBCV) at the preoperative hematocrit (RBCV preop).
  3. Estimate RBCV at a hematocrit of 30% (RBCV 30%), assuming normal blood volume is maintained.
  4. Calculate the RBCV lost when the hematocrit is 30%; RBCV lost = RBCV preop – RBCV 30%
  5. Allowable blood loss = RBCV lost x3.

Blood Volume

Neonates:

  • Premature 95 mL/kg
  • Full-term 85 mL/kg
  • Infants 80 mL/kg

Adults:

  • Men 75 mL/kg
  • Women 65 mL/kg

Estimated blood volume = 65 mL/kg x 75 kg = 4875 mL.

RBCV 35% = 4875 x 35% = 1706 mL.

RBCV 30% = 4875 x 30% = 1462 mL.

Red cell loss at 30% = 1706-1462 = 244 mL.

Allowable blood loss = 3 x 244 mL = 732 ~ 750ml

Therefore, transfusion should be considered only when this patient’s blood loss exceeds 750 ml.

Increasingly, transfusions are not recommended until the hematocrit decreases to 24% or lower (hemoglobin <8.0 g/dL), but it is necessary to take into account the rate of blood loss and comorbid conditions.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl has deliberately drunk phenol in an attempt to commit suicide. She complains of hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach. Which of the following statement is false regarding this?

choices.text: Methaemoglobinaemia is an associated feature in severe cases
It causes numbness by damaging the nerve endings
It is excreted in urine as hydroquinone and pyrocatechol

questions.solution:
Carbolic acid/Phenol is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils contracted

In severe cases, hemolysis and methemoglobinemia are a characteristic feature.

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

In patients with acute poisoning, the stomach should be washed repeatedly. Initially with plenty of lukewarm water containing activated charcoal, olive oil, castor oil, magnesium or sodium sulphate, or saccharated lime with which phenol combines and forms harmless products. A soap solution or 10% glycerine may be used and the washing continued until the washings are clear and odorless.

Once the above is done, the administration of olive oil or vegetable oil is done to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. When lavage is completed, 30 g. of magnesium sulfate or a quantity of medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.

Related Pearl: Urine Color caused by certain Toxins

Urine colours

Causes

Olive green colour urine on standing

Carbolic acid

Grey-black

Phenols, cresols

Opaque appearance which settles on standing

Primidone crystals

Orange or orange-red

Rifampicin, iron (especially after giving desferrioxamine)

Related Pearl: Typical appearance of Stomach Mucosa in some Poisoning

Poison

Appearance of Gastric Mucosa

Arsenic

Red velvety mucosa

H2SO4

Brown or black with erosion perforation and Carbolization

Carbolic acid

Grey leathery and thickened mucosa

HNO3

Yellow

HCN

Pink

KCN

Brick red to brown

Phosphorous

Yellow or grey white

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is in her 8th week of gestation presents with an increased frequency of vomiting which is associated with retching. She shows signs of dehydration and has developed oliguria. Investigations reveal associated ketoacidosis. All of the following are associated with the condition that this patient has, except ____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests hyperemesis gravidarum. Low body mass is a risk factor associated with it(not high).

Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in women with low BMI. Unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough causes weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis, or hypokalemia is known as hypermesis gravidarum.

It is associated with the following factors:

  • First pregnancy
  • Young age
  • Low body mass
  • History of migraine/motion sickness
  • Positive family history
  • Hydatidiform mole and multi-foetal gestation

Patients with hyperemesis gravidarum usually also suffer from a transient clinical or subclinical form of hyperthyroidism.

Management of hyperemesis gravidarum: Mild to moderate symptoms can be treated with dietary modifications,  vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine. Severe cases need IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral ondansetron/metoclopramide/promethazine.

questions.text: Which of the following patients will be classified as stage III (B) according to Ann Arbor staging for Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: A 25 year old male patient who has fever, night sweats and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla
A 25 year old male patient who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms
A 25 year old male patient who has fever and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla
A 25 year old male patient who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms

questions.solution:
A 25-year-old male who has a fever and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla will be classified as stage III (B). Involvement of lymph nodes on both sides of the diaphragm with fever (or night sweats/unexplained weight loss >10%) is stage III (B) of Ann-Arbor staging.

Other Options:

Option B: A 25-year-old male patient who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms will be classified as II (A).

Option C: A 25-year-old male patient who has a fever and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla will be classified as II (B).

Option D: A 25-year-old male patient who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms will be classified as III (A). 

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who has been taking NSAIDs for arthritis for the past 2 years presented to the OPD. He complains of fever, rash, and arthralgia since 1 week. Investigations revealed increased eosinophils in blood and urine, no casts, or crystals in urine. No organism could be cultured from urine. Foley's catheterization was done to monitor the urine output. USG for KUB  revealed the picture as shown below. Kidneys were mildly increased in size. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is acute interstitial nephritis.

Acute interstitial nephritis due to NSAIDs characteristically causes increased eosinophils in blood and urine. The ultrasound image shows maintained corticomedullary differentiation (CMD). Preserved CMD appears as a different echogenicity of cortex and medulla. This finding along with enlarged kidneys makes the diagnosis of acute interstitial nephritis more likely.

Other options:

CKD - Duration of 1 week and enlarged kidney size with preserved corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) makes this unlikely. 

Urethral obstruction - Successful foley catheterization rules out urethral obstruction

ATN - An absence of casts or crystals which are usually seen in ATN are absent in this case. 

In a patient with renal disease, we first try to ascertain if it is acute or chronic. Then the management is decided based on the nature of the renal disease which could be pre-renal, renal, or post-renal:

  Parameter AKI CKD
1 Duration Around 7 days More than 3 months
2 Size Normal or enlarged Shrunken 
3 Corticomedullary
differentiation		 Preserved Lost
4 Complications of CKD Absent  Present
